reviewText:
Brilliant Bob – A Steam Review
[Disclamer - I was provided a copy of by the publisher for review purposes]

The good

Cartoony graphics
Short levels
The not so good:
The jumps are mostly guesses, since you don’t have a shadow under you to see where you’ll land
There is way too much momentum for the player and the moving platforms, you’ll never know when you’ll fall from them because they changed directions or smth. This is even a problem when you’re trying to select a level, most of the time you’ll overshoot your target.
It feels like the menus were made 20 minutes before the game was released. In the first cinematic you can see the tops of the trees from the menu.
The conclusion:
This is an example of a game that would’ve had a lot to gain from doing a beta or early access release. All the problems would’ve been observed and maybe fixed before the release. As it is now, it’s pretty unplayable. On top of that, the high price should make everyone steer away from this.

Overall, I do not recommended Brilliant Bob to anyone. It takes a lot for me to say it, but this game is awful.

reviewText:
Brilliant Bob is a 3D Platformer with a simple plot and diverse environments. The graphics are simple built on the Unity3D Engine making the game look goofy and cartoony. This game probably would have made it in the Top 10 platformers, but there is one huge flaw in this game.

The platforming itself. Yes, the platforming. To beginner players, the controls are odd and very awkward to get used to. The camera is fixed in one position, however you can use Q and E to rotate it. Double jumping is a feature and you need it for almost any jump in this game. The jumping in this game is sadly flawed as the collisions don't like you and you will slide off if you just barely make it. Also, for a platformer, you jump very low and double jumping is absolutely required for every jump in this game except for the ones that you can just walk across. Once you get the hang of it though, you will be able to get the jumps.

The enemies in this game are unrelenting and match your speed making them hard to lose. Slimes, your #1 enemy in the beginner levels, are just as fast as you and hard to kill (throwing crates at them is hard; you can't aim, and they are on you in 3 seconds). The most annoying part about the slimes is that you jump on them like trampolines. No kidding, you can actually use them as trampolines. However, it gets annoying when you try to jump to certain areas or move in a certain direction. I think this game would be better without those damn slimes. Other enemies like the spinning cubes are pretty neat entities. Some levels, you have to jump through them and if you touch the sides, you get hurt. This allows for some pretty tough platforming and some rage-inducing levels which may or may not be fun for some people.

One thing I liked about this game is the physics. Holding shift allows you to move and throw boxes and use them to your advantage when trying
to make a difficult jump. I belive that in some cases, the crates are not needed and only get in the way. However, they do allow you to do some really cool things like jump really far and glitch out the game.

The storyline is a generic Ironic Comedy - The happy town of Sekotwana thrives as Bob lives there for 20 years. However, Dr. Magazi's planet is a sad and lonely one that needs happiness. Magazi then goes to the town of Sekotwana to steal their happiness with his little De-Happiness gun. Ben's parents do not like this and rebel against Dr. Magazi and Bob goes to destroy his Ship. Meanwhile, Bob's parents are kidnapped by Dr. Magazi and Bob must go find his parents before it's too late. The story is simple, easy to follow and comprehend, and somewhat a cliché, but also a fun and
compelling one.

I haven't gotten really far into the game, but I plan to try to beat it. The game is fun for a short time; this game was not meant to be played in a 2 hour binge, marathon or speedrun. If you get this game, it is best to play it in short bursts or it will get very annoying very quickly.

If there is someone out there with an account for their child, then this is a must-buy. This game is a good one for children, but teens and adults probably won't be interested in it.
Also, I got this game for 29 cents. Please, spare your money and do not buy this game for the full price ($9.99 at the time of writing). The game can be fun, but it is not worth that much money.

reviewText:
Per Wikipedia, the first 3D platforming game was Alpha Waves in 1990.  The breakthrough game that changed 3D platforming from a technical showpiece to an accepted genre was, of course, Super Mario 64 in 1996.  As the form improved, developers gradually found tricks to work around the biggest stumbling block of the genre; that even though you render your environment in 3D, a TV screen or a PC monitor is still 2D -- there is only the illusion of depth.

Zonitron Productions, sadly, has not learned these tricks.  So their 3D platformer is an exercise in frustration.  It's difficult to tell whether a platform is small-but-close or large-but-far.  Once Bob is in the air, it's a matter of pure guesswork where he lands.  Jumping Flash! handled 3D platforming much better than this in 1995, a year before Mario's version.

Although the story is far from brilliant
date: as described, and the gameplay lacking, the devs clearly put some effort into this game.  The levels look nice, and feature a well-detailed floor" for you to admire as you plunge to your doom.  Brilliant Bob suffers mainly from inexperience.  The ability to design and build a set of 3D platforming stages just isn't enough to make a playable 3D platformer."

reviewText:
It's pretty obvious this asset was used to make the game: https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/en/#!/content/11786

Found a few other Unity Assets as well.

I have no problem with people using pre-made assets to make a game - However you would expect at least a remodel to be done or change the color, or systems tweaked to be unique.

That said, this game is a collection of Assets from the Unity Store which were flung together and called a game. You would be better off buying the assets yourself and making a fun game out of it because the assets work pretty much the same way Brilliant Bob does, right out of the box.
